entry.title: Prusa Mendel I2 (Re)build
entry.content:
This spring I purchased a partially completed Prusa Mendel i2 hobby 3D printer from another student at RIT. On initial inspection the printer looked fully assembled, but didn’t have the correct software. In all actuality, there was still quite a bit to fix before it would be ready to print.

Software Fixes

The printer itself was an (almost) complete kit that was technically assembled, but very poorly. I initially focused on getting functioning firmware on the printer and checking that the wiring was fine. You can find my fork of the open source Sprinter firmware here. The printer uses the Sanguinololu 1.2 board and Pololu motor drivers to run each of the steppers. Luckily, all of the motors worked when I configured the firmware so I could focus on the hardware.

Hardware Fixes

The printer had a few notable issues: it was missing a print bed, the carriage was actually a cheap photo frame (seriously), and the previous owner had thought it was a good idea to hot glue the heating element in. Here’s a photo of the hot glued extruder mount.

I fixed the issues with the glue in the extruder by designing and printing a bracket for the J-head extruder on a lab 3D printer. The bracket tightly holds the hot end in place vertically; it had previously just flopped around and fallen out when the hot end was heated. Which is why you don’t hold something hot with hot glue.

After fixing the x-axis and installing the bracket I noticed that the carriage for the y-axis was held together by hot glue as well. On closer inspection, I realized that the carriage was actually a cheap picture frame held together by glue and a few staples.

With some help and suggestions from friends working in the lab, I ended up laser cutting a particle board replacement for the photo frame. It turned out pretty well, but somehow I accidentally scaled it down while cutting so the holes for mounting the heated bed are too close to the edge.

I also needed to put a print surface over the heated bed on the printer. A friend in the lab introduced me to Garolite, a type of plastic that sticks to ABS well, and found a piece that I could use. I used a vertical band saw to cut it to size and then drilled holes for the mount. Additionally, I got some springs to fit underneath the bed so it can be easily leveled.

Calibration

After completing all of the crucial hardware fixes, I was able to spend some time zeroing the printer and doing calibration prints. I found that my timing belt on the y-axis was too angled at the ends, so I made some new timing belt clamps and a friend made a new pulley.

I then worked on correcting the scale of the prints, making sure each axis was moving correct distances. This took some time but eventually they moved set distances reliably. Unfortunately, I was only able to do a few short calibration prints after that before having to store the printer for the summer. I’ll have the opportunity to test out some larger prints when I return to school in August.

Thanks

I would never have been able to complete so much work on the printer without the help and resources of a lot of people in the lab at RIT. They helped me out even when I wasn’t confident that I could fix any part of it, and that was exactly what I needed.

entry.title: Fixing the Samsung Galaxy
entry.content:
I’ve had a Samsung Galaxy S4 smartphone for a year now and it’s a good phone. However, the software that Samsung has put on top of stock android can be really awful in places and I’ve spent lots of time finding fixes. My phone runs the stock KitKat launcher, uses stock Google service apps, does all of its media from Google Play, and uses the stock Google camera app. These apps not only look much better visually, but provide a much better service than anything Samsung produces. Here’s how to set up these fixes on any device running Android KitKat or newer.

Google Now Launcher

Touchwiz (the Samsung touch interface) manages to be one of the most feature rich skins of Android, without being particularly useful or visually appealing. Meanwhile, Google did a great job with the latest KitKat Launcher: Google Now integration, voice search, transparencies, and a clean UI. I’ve found the stock Google launcher to be a much better Android experience, and it is possible to get it on any KitKat phone.

1. Google Search: Make sure you have the Google Search app. It contains the KitKat Launcher.

2. Launcher APK: Download this apk and install it to allow you to use Google Search as your launcher.

3. Setup: Press the home button and set “Launcher” as the default launcher. That’s it.

Apps

1. Camera: The Google Camera app is much better than the stock Samsung one (at least for photos). Get it here.

2. Messaging: Google Hangouts is a much cleaner messaging app, which allows merged conversations between your Google account and sms. Get it here.

3. Calendar: Plain Google calendar app. Found here.

4. Music: Google Play Music is a really convenient service for managing and playing music. Download Google Music Manager on your computer to upload songs to your account, then get the app to listen to your library. You can change how your account stores music (so you don’t use data) in the settings tab of the app. This includes storing music on the SD card.

5. Lock Screen: I like having all of my notifications displayed while still having a phone lock. So far SlideLock is the best lock screen add on I’ve used, although it can be slow for a while when you first use it.

6. Keyboard: Swiftkey combines customizable themes, swiping, and adaptive auto correct to make typing much easier. Get it here.

entry.title: Artificial Intelligence for Gobblet
entry.content:
Recently I had the opportunity to design an AI to play the board game “Gobblet” for a team-based class project. At the end of the project all of the AIs entered in to a tournament against each other to determine which strategies were the most effective. My team’s AI ended up making it to the department finals; performing well against a variety of Gobblet strategies. Here I’m going to explain the basis of how our AI player was designed.

Rules of Gobblet

To begin with I’ll explain the basic rules of Gobblet. The game is played on a 4X4 grid using stackable cups in four sizes (ranging 1-4). Players take turns placing cups from their stacks on the board, trying to create a line of four of their pieces in a row. However, players also have the option of covering up cups of smaller sizes on the board when moving. This creates an interesting gameplay where covering up the other player’s pieces can be more useful than placing in a free space. A more detailed set of rules can be found here.

Design of an AI

Creating an AI for a board game is basically like creating a system of ranking moves. Each turn your program has to look at the current state of the board and in some way or another determine what possible move is best. First, our AI would take the current state of the board and generate every possible move we could make from it. Then it would determine which of the generated moves were valid and rank them to find the most ideal one.

Our Strategy

The strategy we ended up using didn’t end up looking in to future moves, or searching for complicated strategies. Instead it focused on creating a progression of board states that creates a win. Here’s some examples:

1. Winning: Make a move if it creates a four-in-a-row.

2. Losing: Discard moves where the opponent has an unblocked three-in-a-row or a four-in-a-row. Also discard any moves where they have intersecting two-in-a-rows. (I’ll discuss this.)

3. Empty Rows: Add points for each row where we have a piece and the opponent does not. Helps us start runs.

4. Pieces in Stacks: Add points to a move if we have more pieces left than the opponent. We found this makes winning a long game more likely.

5. Gobbles: Add points for each piece we have “gobbled” (covered up). We found that while creating runs it was useful to gobble as frequently as possible, because it ensures that we have more pieces on the board. Unfortunately, it also means you have more difficulty moving pieces because they might uncover opponent’s pieces.

The final part of our strategy focuses on creating a scenario where we have two intersecting three-in-a-rows in order to win. When you create a single three-in-a-row, it is easy for your opponent to see you are going to win and block it. However, if you create two three-in-a-rows in the same turn it is impossible to block - giving you the win one turn later. In order to achieve this we added a few more rankings.

6. Two-in-a-Rows: Add a few points for creating (unblocked) two-in-a-rows somewhere.

7. Intersecting Two-in-a-Rows: Add more points for creating two-in-a-rows that intersect.

8. Intersecting Three-in-a-Rows: Add a substantial amount of points for creating intersecting three-in-a-rows.

Shortcomings

The strategy we chose works well for basic gameplay and setting up useful situations, but it far from perfect. Most notably, the AI doesn’t adapt to opposing playing styles – instead focusing on forming set situations. Additionally, it often followed the same pattern each time it played another AI (no randomness). There’s plenty of different scenarios to think about when designing these programs.

entry.title: Getting Started: About This Site
entry.content:
The last few weeks I’ve been working on developing this website as a place to post projects and thoughts as well as get more experience with web development. It’s finally at a point where I’m content with the styling and layout (for the moment) so I thought it would be good to post some of what I’ve learned so far.

When I originally planned on developing a site a year ago, I was daunted with the task of creating one from scratch. I didn’t want to use a pre-built platform, because you lose a lot of control of the site and can’t learn anything from it. This site is generated by Octopress, a static site generator that adds features to Jekyll. Websites built using Octopress/Jekyll are generated locally, meaning that the site is assembled each time a change is made. This avoids the problem of having to work with databases and allows me to have full control over the appearance of the site.

Another bonus to having a static site is the ability to use git for version control and Github Pages for free hosting. Each time I want to update the site, I commit the most recent changes to the site’s repository on Github and the site is hosted from there. This system makes it really easy to maintain the site and keeps the cost of running it down. Additionally, I can still use my own domain name when accessing the site.

In summary, Octopress makes creating a static site really simple, while holding on to the customization that I want. Nice!
